byline.contributor: Rebecca R. Ruiz reported from Washington, and Steve Lohr from New York.
byline.original: By REBECCA R. RUIZ and STEVE LOHR

abstract: Federal Communications Commission votes 3-2 along party lines to regulate broadband Internet service as public utility; net neutrality rules are meant to ensure that no content is blocked and that Internet is not split into pay-to-play fast lanes for companies and slow lanes for others.
lead_paragraph: The agency’s 3-2 vote is intended to ensure a level playing field for Internet content providers, with no so-called pay-to-play fast lanes.

headline.main: F.C.C. Approves Net Neutrality Rules, Classifying Broadband Internet Service as a Utility
headline.print_headline: F.C.C. Votes to Regulate the Internet as a Utility

snippet: The agency’s 3-2 vote is intended to ensure a level playing field for Internet content providers, with no so-called pay-to-play fast lanes.
